DOC.HEAD: Political Negotiations Resume in Controversy
DOC.TEXT: The head of a new East German opposition party today withdrew from talks between East Germany's coalition government and other opposition groups after he was accused of corruption. The announcement came as the talks, which concern the future course of the country, resumed today after a Christmas break. Wolfgang Schnur, chairman of the Democratic Awakening Party, was accused in the newspaper Junge Welt of using his position to obtain a large apartment that originally had been allocated to a family with several children. The 45-year-old lawyer denied the allegations but said he was withdrawing from the talks until the matter had been clarified. He said he was the target of a ``massive campaign'' aimed at discrediting him and his party politically, and he claimed his mother, who is Jewish, has received threats from neo-Nazis. Schnur, elected chairman of Democratic Awakening earlier this month when the opposition group met to constitute itself as a political party, said he would seek a vote of confidence from the party board. Since the fall of hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18, East Germans have been intent on rooting out corruption. Most such allegations have centered on the top levels of the now-ousted Communist Party leadership. East German leaders have instituted dizzying changes following protests by hundreds of thousands of people for democratic reform. It opened the Berlin Wall as part of loosened travel restrictions in November, promised free elections and called for the talks between Communist and opposition leaders. Honecker's successor, Egon Krenz, also resigned as president and a non-Communist replaced him in a new coalition government, which includes the Communists and four traditionally allied parties. Communist Premier Hans Modrow is handling day-to-day affairs until the free elections. The talks involve 37 representatives from five established political parties, including the Communists, and representatives of 16 opposition groups. The discussion group is acting as a watchdog group on Modrow's government until the elections May 6. Junge Welt, a youth-oriented newspaper once closely allied with the Communists, made the allegations against Schnur. Schnur's party has maintained close contacts with West German officials but is split on the question of reunification. It has also called for a free market system in East Germany, although there is a dispute on this topic as well. His movement has existed as a party for only two weeks, and its national influence is still hard to assess. Schnur said he would sue the newspaper, which has become increasingly independent and aggressive in its reporting. Schnur also said his mother received anonymous letters containing threats from neo-Nazis. East German leaders have said they are on guard against a possible rise in nationalist and neo-Nazi groups, as a result of the turmoil gripping the Communist country.
